[vc_column_text]“What are the top benefits of studying in Canada for international students?”

People from all the corners of the world desire to immigrate to Canada, which firmly supports multiculturalism. Canadians have a reputation for being among the friendliest people in the world thanks to their warmth and hospitality as well as their embrace of diversity.

Canadian Colleges and Universities welcome thousands of international students from numerous countries each year. Learn more about the top 10 benefits of studying in Canada for international students in this comprehensive guide.[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text]

1. High Standard of Living

t’s no secret that Canada boasts one of the highest standards of living in the world. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), the average Canadian household has a net disposable income of USD $34,421 per year. This is higher than the OECD average figure of USD $30,490.

The average life expectancy in Canada is also around 82. This is higher than the OECD average figure, which is 81. Canada is also known for its high education quality. In fact, it has 31 Universities that are considered among the best in the world.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”2. Easy Study Permit Process” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”eligibility”][vc_column_text]The Canadian economy greatly benefits from the funds that international students pour into it. For this reason, the Canadian Government has made it easy for such students to come to Canada.

Anyone that has received admission to a Canadian College or University can apply for a Canada student visa or Canada study permit using a straightforward process. This includes demonstrating that you:

  • Have been accepted to a Canadian College or University
  • Possess the funds to pay your tuition and living expenses while studying in Canada
  • Are in good health
  • Do not have a criminal record
[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”3. Affordable Living Costs and Tuition Fees” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”requirements”][vc_column_text]Many international students from developed countries flock to Canada for its affordable living costs. For example, countries like Switzerland and Singapore have a Cost-of-Living index of 123 and 83, respectively. By contrast, Canada’s Cost-of-Living index is only 70.

Canada also has relatively low tuition fees compared to other developing countries. For example, the tuition fees for undergraduate programs range from $23,000 to $80,000 annually in the United States. By contrast, the tuition fees for undergraduate programs range from $15,000 to $60,000 annually in Canada.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner equal_height=”yes” content_placement=”middle” column_margin=”default” column_direction=”default” column_direction_tablet=”default” column_direction_phone=”default” top_padding=”5%” bottom_padding=”5%” text_align=”left”][vc_column_inner column_padding=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_tablet=”inherit” column_padding_phone=”inherit” column_padding_position=”all” column_element_spacing=”default” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”1/2″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”none” column_border_style=”solid”][image_with_animation image_url=”12237″ animation=”None” hover_animation=”none” alignment=”” border_radius=”none” box_shadow=”none” image_loading=”default” max_width=”100%” max_width_mobile=”default”][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner column_padding=”padding-6-percent” column_padding_tablet=”inherit” column_padding_phone=”inherit” column_padding_position=”all” column_element_spacing=”default” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”1/2″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”1px” column_border_color=”#707070″ column_border_style=”solid”][vc_column_text]

Work While Studying in Canada” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”pathways”][vc_column_text]Another advantage of studying in Canada for international students is being able to work. Few countries allow international students to work while simultaneously completing an education program, so Canada stands out in this regard.

As an international student, you can work on campus for unlimited hours during your semester. You can also work up to 20 hours per week off campus without requiring a work permit. This arrangement is helpful because you can earn extra money to cover your living expenses in the country. This is why international students choose Canada to study.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”5. Obtain a Post-Graduate Work Permit” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]Studying in Canada also provides another key work-related benefit: A post-graduate work permit.
This special work permit is issued to international students upon completing their education program in Canada. It is valid for 1 to 3 years, depending on the length of your program.

The Post-Graduate Work Permit work permit is incredibly valuable because you do not need a job offer to apply for it. This means you can start earning work experience in Canada without facing the work permit application challenges that people who live outside must go through.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”6. Apply at Any Age” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]The Canadian Government doesn’t discriminate between young international students and mature international students because it acknowledges that everyone deserves to have access to Canada’s high-quality education. This means you can apply for a Canada study visa after a long gap in your education.

This is advantageous for mature students who want to gain additional education qualifications to progress in their careers.

Related Post: Canada Study Visa After 5-25 years Long Gap[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”7. Gain Permanent Residency” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]Many international students who come to Canada grow to love the country and its way of life. Such students often wish to settle in the country after completing their studies. The good news is that such students have an easy pathway to permanent residency.

Once you have finished your University or College program, you should gain a minimum of 1 year of work experience in Canada while your Post-Graduate Work Permit is valid. You can then apply for permanent residence under Express Entry’s Canadian Express Class program.

Thousands of international students receive Canadian permanent residence through this pathway each year because it is easy.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”8. Provincial Health Card” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]Healthcare can be expensive for people without insurance in most developed countries. This is especially true for foreign students who typically do not receive the Government-provided healthcare assistance that citizens enjoy.

The good news is that international students in Canada will receive a provincial health card during their study program. This health card will cover a wide range of healthcare costs for them.

This means you won’t have to worry about paying high hospital bills if you fall ill or get injured while studying in Canada.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”9. Safe and Peaceful Environment” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”benefits”][vc_column_text]Canada is also notable for providing international students with a safe and peaceful environment. The country is both politically and economically stable. This means that street crime and violent crime rates are relatively low.
International students can roam freely without running into the dangers or discrimination they might experience in less-safe countries.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”10. Open Work Permit for Spouse” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]Many international students also choose Canada for the Canada student visa benefits for spouse. If you are married and have received a Canadian student visa, your spouse will be eligible to apply for an open work permit. This means they can accompany you to Canada and work in the country while you complete your education program at a Canadian College or University.

Learn more: Canada’s Open Work Permit for International Student’s Spouse[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”Need help?” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]There are several motivations for international students to study in Canada. With its top-notch universities and colleges, this nation aids people in improving their educational credentials and gives them the chance to get permanent residency.
